DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Denounces Separatist Sentiments
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev lashed out Saturday at secessionist sentiments threatening to pull his country apart, charging that they were leading to ``conflict and blood and death.'' Gorbachev, jabbing his hands in the air, spoke to the Congress of People's Deputies. A Communist Party Central Committee was expected Sunday to discuss the Lithuanian party decision to break with the national party. ``To realize the right to self-determination through secession means to blow up the union, set people against each other and sow conflict and blood and death,'' Gorbachev told the Congress. ``That's what separatists are pushing us toward.'' The Congress broke into applause. Gorbachev has tried hard over the last several months to prevent the Lithuanians from abandoning the national Communist Party. He reacted with anger when it made its decision Wednesday. The Lithuanian party move is part of a long-range program to restore the independence that the small Baltic republic enjoyed between the world wars. Later Saturday, the Congress balked at a declaration denouncing the 1939 Nazi-Soviet pact that led to the absorption of Lithuania and two other Baltic lands, Latvia and Estonia, into the Soviet Union. The declaration received 1,052 votes _ 70 short of the majority required for approval. A total of 678 deputies voted ``no.'' Supporters said they would try to win approval once more on Sunday, the final day of the Congress. With its vote, the Congress ``demonstrated its conservatism,'' said Estonian deputy Marju Lauristen. ``Fifty years later, they prefer to sleep with Stalin's dreams.'' The resolution was supported by Baltic deputies who claim their homelands were victims of dictator Josef Stalin's aggression. It would condemn as invalid the secret protocol of the Soviet-Nazi non-aggression pact on the eve of World War II. In Lithuania, activists reported that the republic's Communist Party had split in two, one party professing loyalty to its mother party in Moscow and another, larger party that has declared its independence from Moscow. The activist Lithuanian people's front, known as Sajudis, reported that party members who had opposed breaking off from Moscow had formed their own leadership in a ``factual split'' from the independent party.
